text: yawning we all know it's contagious and
not only in people
chimps catch each other's yawns too
scientists see this contagious yawning
as part of the social glue that binds us
all together so it's not surprising that
it occurs in other social species too
like chimpanzees and baboons what's
really interesting is that it works
across species at a sanctuary in Sierra
Leone scientists set up an experiment in
which caretakers and unfamiliar human
beings yawned in front of 33 orphaned
chimpanzees
the awning was clearly contagious
whether the chimps knew the honor or not
but only if the chimps were at least
five years old and that's the same with
children although the age for kids is
four and that was the real point of the
study to see if the ability to catch a
yawn develops at the same time that
awareness of others takes a big leap
forward and it does contagious yawning
as mundane as it is seems to be a
signpost for something deeper the
development of empathy and its presence
and other animals suggests that its
evolutionary roots run deep
you
